FIRST CASE BY EXPRESS.

NEW SPRING AND SUMMER MILLINERY.
BRANDON.
From the Blade, March 6.
The weather is chilly.
The new Goose Wing shoe club had a
triumph Tuesday evening.
A long year's work is to be held to-
morrow evening in the Methodist Church.
The teaching staff in the Church has
been greatly appreciated.
There are now forty prisoners in the Provincial jail at Winnipeg.
The curling season ended in a defeat
for the west end.
PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE MILLINERY.
From the Blade, March 6.
Mr. W. H. Baker has presented the
Portage Curling Club with a handsome
medal.
The snow show held the best teams
of the season on Tuesday evening.
A feature of the skating carnival next
week will be a tug of war on ice.
The Rev. J. R. Silcox will begin his
lecture on Martin Luther here at an
early date.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.
Gathered humor Reporters.
The weather during the past week has
been very fine.
Twenty pounds of goods arrived for T. O.
last Tuesday.
It was thought that the river will break
up in about three weeks.
MESSRS. J. M. Campbell and H. Reid
left for carref on Wednesday.
MESSRS. J. O. Duff have come to Carref
for five days.
The proclamation effecting this place
into an incorporated town is expected by
the end of the month.
The Hudson's Bay Company gave an air
concert on Monday evening, last, on the
road of J. O. Davis & Co.'s.
The Hudson's Bay Company has been
offered the franchise of the spring and summer
season of millinery and fancy goods.
The Indians are beginning to move
across the country in a pretty great
quantity, and that the spring is near.
T. E. Jackson, chairman, is expecting in
large supply of fancy goods and drug
store materials.
Gouldfellow Bros. have got out a large
number of logs this winter and will com-
mence setting shingles in a few days.
Judgment day is coming, and the beauti-
ful will soon be a thing of the past.
The last man of the past week having re-
ceived it cannot be seen.
We shall see Mr. R. Middleton around
the Woodley Hill Ballad once more.
Mr. Donovan having engaged some-
time to assist in baking after the heat
has passed.
Mr. W. W. Clarke left for Winnipeg
yesterday morning.
He will return
about four o'clock.
He was joined by Mr. Ting, who goes to Qua-
ppelle to reside on his claims near that
place.
Last Monday being St. Patrick's day
some of our local sports arranged for
a special event.
The day which followed was very satis-
factory.
Several jocular changes hand-
somely assisted the proceedings.
Throughout the skating rink field the
snow from springing in the back-up
poor McKay's hall.
The ice is good
condition, and during the last few days
it has been very smooth.
The ice is being used for skating on the
other rinks.
RAT PORTEGE.
From the Progress, March 6.
Mr. C. E. Fay is entering a large house
near town for his own con-
venience.
Ontario Consolidated Gold Mining
Company will resume work at Char-
water Bay next week.
Mr. C. E. Fay will open a gymnastic
and training school next week.
Unusually eight registered letters left the
post office yesterday.
The Ontario Government has granted
$500 in aid of the school here.

STONEHALL.
From the New Era, March 6.
A petition for dissolution to meet
Mrs. Craig, whose husband was lost in a
snow storm about a month ago.
Mr. Airth, a wealthy farmer living in
Regina, has been missing for several days.
He was found dead in his bed on Saturday
morning of the last week.
Heart disease.
Roads in bad condition.
Starch seeds are being planted.
New Era, Feb. 29.
The driving snow and the Altitude of the
night was very severe along the new England coast.
The steamer "Alta" was delayed but the crew was rescued.
The steam-
ship "Crescent" was delayed during the
night but later floated unharmed.

OCONFLAGRATION.
A $40,000 BLAZE.
The Hudson's Bay Company's
Grain Mill Reduced to Ashes
and a Large Quantity of Grain Destroyed.
Late Friday night, about 11:30 p.m., an
alarm of fire was heard simultaneous
from both ends of the town, and
everybody rushed out to find what
had happened in the Hudson's Bay mill.
A three storey frame building filled with
machinery.
On the sounding of the
alarm the firemen, the constables,
the brigade and the employees and officials
of the Company rushed to the scene of
the building.
A hose, with which the fire
was provided, was put together and at-
tached to the hydrant.
The end of
the hose was taken up to the second
floor, the intention of confining the flames
being to prevent the spread.
This was
soon found to be impracticable, as the
hose was driven to the lower floor by the fall-
ing chinders and blinding smoke, and the
fire was soon beyond control.
The building was doomed.
A large
quantity of grain in bags was got out of
the building by the firemen with a
machine, but the intense heat caused
everybody away from the burning build-
ing.
Attention was then turned to the
saving of a large quantity of lumber in
the mill, which was filled with
wooden structures.
A fireman was thrown
into the air by fire and water.
The so-
diers and volunteers came to the scene
days after the putting in of some new
and valuable machinery, by which an
amount of flour was being saved.
It
will be seen that the loss will be very
great, as we are sure left with but
one storehouse mill in this large
district.
The building and
plant cost $10,000, which it is to be
hoped the Company will replace during
the coming season.
The fire was caused by the citizens generally who turned out
so promptly and worked so energetically
to save the property.
The fire is supposed to
have originated in the upper part of the
engine room, which was filled with
oil.
Mr. Dobson, the miller, said that
having just been around the upper stories
and stated that everything was running
smoothly and correct.

TERRITORIAL NEWS.
QUAPPILLE.
From the New Era, March 6.
The weather is very mild and the snow
is disappearing fast.
The bushes of Troy intend to give a
charity ball in March.
Mr. Baker, the municipal agent, said
that a large number of new
grants will arrive to settle in this neigh-
borhood this spring.

MOOSE JAW.
From the New Era, March 7.
The tobogganing slide is again in good
condition.
An address and presentation to Mr. J.
H. Brown, railway mail clerk, took
place on Tuesday evening, the occasion
being his departure.
Mr. J. H. Whitmore has a brace of
hounds, who ran down and captured a
wolf.
As they have never had any train
before, it is not known how well bred dogs
inhabit this district.

A number of half breed traders from
Wood Mountain were in town purchas-
ing flour stores.

Preparations are being made for an
early start in the building boom during
the coming summer.

TELEGRAPHIC.
PARLIAMENT IN SESSION.
Norquay's Government sus-
tained by a Majority of 19.
A Big Scandal in Toronto.
Attempt made to Bribe Three
of Morant's Supporters.
Morant Denounces Them on
the Floor of the House.
The Money Counted out on
the Clerk's Table.
Arrival of the Guilty Parties.
The Police Magistrates committeemen have
been instructed to bring them in.
The Butter Ringup in the House and
Investigation going on.
Members who revealed the plot have
been denounced by the Opposition.
Great Excitement in Ottawa, Toronto and
Winnipeg.
Another Hudson's Bay Railway Bill Introduced.
The seduction bill likely to be Defeated in
Committee.
Special Service to the Times.
WINNIPEG, March 20.—The Local
House met on the 15th inst., and is now
in session.
Special interest has been taken
in Mr. Norquay's bill, and it is
hoped that the same will be a
majority of nineteen.
A big scandal has been brought to
light in Toronto.
Butting of the Mail, Ed Monk, bar-
rister, Wilkinson, of pig pen fame, and
Kilgour, were sworn in to three sup-
porters of Morant, who were charged
with conspiring to run Morant out of
the House.
They were also promised
promotions in the West.
The members took the money,
and appeared to fall into the scheme, while
all the time they were telling the truth.
All have been denounced in the
House, causing the utmost con-
sternation amongst the conspirators, and
Morant was counted out on
the clerk's table.
Warrants were issued for the arrest of
William Wilkinson, who were ar-
rested and secured in Toronto police
lock-up.
Butting and Monk are out on bail, but
half has been refused for the others.
All four have been before the Police
Magistrates, who committed them for
trial.
The matter has been brought up in
the House, and an investigation is now
going on.
The members who revealed the plot
have been denounced by the Opposition
on the Floor of the House.
There is great excitement in Ottawa, Toronto and
here is intense.
It is said the money was furnished by
the Sinn Feiners, who are implicated,
and will likely be arrested.
The indignation is intense.
Some fresh and startling developments are
expected.
Butting of the Mail has nothing to
say in reference to the matter.
OTTAWA, March 20.—Intense excite-
ment is felt here over the Toronto bribery
affair.
Another Hudson Bay Railway bill has
been introduced in the House.
Mr. Chalmers's induction bill, which
was passed by the House, is likely to be
defeated in the Senate.
REGINA.
From the Leader, March 6.
A social in aid of the funds of the
Methodist Church will be held on
March 10.
The next sitting of the District Court
of the first Judicial District will be held
tomorrow at Regina.
A concert will be held on the
11th inst., in aid of the Ladies' Aid So-
ciety of the Presbyterian Church.
OUR GRIEVANCES.

It has been our misfortune to have to devote much of our time to remonstrances against laws which we only wish we could hope they would be to soon relieved of this unpleasant duty. The task of complaint and remonstrance accompanied by the prayer for relief has so far proved too heavy a load to bear; the heads of the settlers in the Territories the accusation of being unreasonable grumblers, and impossible to satisfy. So long as the government continues to be represented by those who presume to pass judgment upon matters with which they have no practical knowledge, so long will their feelings be affected by their sentiments or opinions, and we consider that to answer them seriously would be at once to waste our time and unnecessarily increase the amount of our own exaggerated sense of our own importance. There are however a good many men who with more sympathy for the hardships of other, and more highly educated observers, are justly disposed to join the protestant voices of humanity referred to, yet constantly impress upon us the necessity of waiting patiently for the correction of the "present evil." While we freely admit that a man with a grievance more, along with many of them, is apt to be anything but a "job," we must confess that some degree of encouragement for the exercise of patience in various directions, could we discover any inclination to afford us voluntarily and spontaneously justice in others, it is decidedly discouraging to hear it said that, and that, and that for the very grievances, which, the principles and facts involved being undisputed, might be remedied by a scratch of the pen. Now while the utmost possible and most unexpected rapidity with which everything has poured into the Territories has rendered it difficult if not impossible for the government to keep pace with the changed conditions, things in every respect still are not optimistic; and there has been given to effect some more obvious alterations demanded by the new order of things. We presume that the declaration of war which was issued from the hands of granting monarchs to the safe guards of their rights and liberties contained in "Magna Charta," Bill of Rights—"Grands" Constitution—Habeas Corpus—Act of Settlement, etc., must be fairly alive to what their constitutional rights consist of—and when they remember that the stroke of the axe, deprived King Charles I. of his liberty, and thus threatened Divine Right of kings in our fathers' land, and the attempt to tax without a parliament—it is not likely that we will long submit to taxation without representation. However while we feel so perfectly easy as to getting such an open violation of our rights as this redressed, by all means let us be patient. With regard to settling the existence of another deliberative and flagrant outrage on our liberties as free men, we do not feel justified in counselling a further exercise of that most excellent virtue, by which the way may easily be opened for our degeneracy into vice. We refer to the exercise in our midst of men armed with the monstrous, extraordinary, abnormal and utterly unconstitutional (when combined) powers of Police Officers. We do not altogether condemn their desire to reflect upon the appointment in the past of those "softening and complete unmitigating legal extremes." We are prepared to believe that in times past by circumstances of the country may have rendered their existence a necessary evil. Furthermore, we must not be misjudged into believing that any such act, or group of individuals of the combination order. What we oppose is the violation of a principle, the encroachment on our liberties. We believe that the same men, vessels, and strange powers, also, have, exercises been with such moderation and regard to the liberty of the subject, as their individual lights and the admonition of their own consciences, allow, but now, more than ever, we totally object, as British subjects, to being at the mercy of the Mounted Police Force taken together, has been made evident to each and every one, it must be desirable to let the men themselves, as well as the general public, understand more exactly the precise manner of their duties, and the nature of their acts, we sincerely acknowledge that such action is to be thanked to have been undertaken by municipal machinery enables us to dispense with their services, and to make use of the services of persons and privileges to their officers, unless under most exceptional circumstances, as we have already stated, we utterly refuse to humiliate. It is not within our province to say whether, or even watch the proceedings of police courts, be the police as well meaning as possible, how often this magistrates have to protest the most aggravating and outrageous conduct on their part. Again, just as it is well-known to medical men, that members of their profession who have made the study of lunacy a specialty, commonly discover, at least as sound as them selves, so does the police mind tend to find evidences of guilt, which are hidden from the less professional minds of jurymen and civic men. In addition to this, there must exist in the mind of the officer, although he may be quite unconscious of it, a strong pre-disposition when acting as a magistrate, to pronounce support of the action of his subordinates. Does this, added to the professional arbitrariness incidental to his position, render him a suitable judge to take the oath and estimate the value of evidence on a summary trial? Were this all it would be bad enough, but it seems hardly credible that such a monstrosity elementary as exists in this day, and in this country, exists as a man who within himself contains the power to order an information to be laid against a free man, arrest him, sit in judgment upon his conduct, and then lock him up and act as his gaoler, or fine him and levy a distress. If anything further be wanted to complete the impiety of such a possibility as this, it may be found in the facts that there are probably more offenses involving the possibility of a six months incarceration dealt with by justices of the peace in the Territories than elsewhere, and that from their decision there seems, in hardly any cases, to be any appeal. That this discreditible state of things must exist cannot have caused more trouble, nor largely be ascribed to the fact that there are few places of any size where either stipendiary nor local magistrates are within reasonable access, whereas in such places the good sense and taste of police officers generally induce them to send cases to be dealt with by them, in preference to irritating the public by the exercise of powers merely intended to be exercised when other cases are open. It is obvious however that such a matter as this must not be left to good taste of individuals. It is the possibility of such undesirable powers existing in the midst of the isolated communities of Her Majesty's subjects, that must promptly cease. If such still exist spots so remote that not only police officers, but magistrates, have ever visited, then let them be made clearly to understand that under such circumstances alone are they to act in that capacity. It may not be possible to prevent the doing of an evil we shall not have in creating, but it certainly is our duty to insist that one be found. Should this continue we will begin to speculate seriously as to whether the public sentiment is being not very gradually eroded for the reception of a military dictatorship.
